description: A snow-white flower also known as wild bergamot.  Smells faintly of mint.
//: red variety as theres no data on Monarda fistulosa, but this is similar enough - <https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7356345/table/plants-09-00691-t002/>

description: An almost forgotten staple of the native tribes, called the Indian potato by some.  Very nutritious, but mildly toxic unless cooked.
This aromatic rhizome can be eaten as is in an emergency, but it is much better used for making beverages.  Its taste is pleasant but it is also tough and stringy.
A slightly sweet tuber.  Contains much inulin which may cause some minor issues with your digestive tract, so it should be cooked.
Also called ramps, this delicate leafy vegetable is healthy and a tasty ingredient for many dishes.
//: no flags like CATTLE because most wildlife actually hate the onion smell

description: A big stalk of broccoli.  It's a bit tough, but rich in Vitamin C and quite delicious when properly cooked.
A head of crisp white cabbage.  You should probably prepare it before eating.
//: Actually, not recommended for rats and mice to eat in big quantities because gas but no way to implement that yet, very minor detail though

description: A handful of shredded cabbage.
Edible leaves of the grape vine.  Typically used in salads or as a food wrapping.
A handful of crunchy red radish taproots.
A bunch of spinach leaves.  Their ability to provide one with superhuman strength has been greatly exaggerated by popular media.
A healthy root vegetable.  Rich in vitamin A!
//: Carrots are somewhat high in sugar and should only be eaten sparingly by rabbits but there is no way to implement that yet

description: A stout, branching rhizome from a cattail plant.  Its crisp white flesh is very starchy and fibrous, but you really ought to cook it before you attempt to eat it.
The rhizome of the lotus, which has many tubular cavities inside, can be eaten both raw and cooked.
A stiff, green stalk from a cattail plant.  It is starchy and fibrous, but it would be much better if you cooked it.
A stiff, green stalk from a plant.  It is starchy and fibrous, but it would be much better if you cooked it.
A single stalk of celery.  Neither tasty nor very nutritious, but it goes well with salad.
//: It appears that celery is energy-negative for rodents

description: A tough protective capsule bulging with densely-packed fibers and seeds, this cotton boll can be processed into usable material with the right tools.
A spicy chili pepper.  Not the best on its own, but adds great flavor when used in cooking.
//: Birds can eat spicy stuff easily due to their inability to taste spiciness

description: A chili pepper that's been cut into pieces.  The seeds have been removed.
The larger cousin of a pickle.  A vegetable from the gourd family.  Not especially flavorful, but very refreshing.
//: No data on cows finding cucumbers super tasty

description: A chopped-up salad cucumber.
A pickle before it becomes a pickle.  Gherkins are smaller cucumbers that - you guessed it - are used to make pickles.
A chopped-up gherkin cucumber.
The large, tuberous root of a dahlia flower.  It smells spicy, but is too starchy to eat without cooking.
//: Dahlia roots contain an incredible amount of vitamin B6. This isn't a vitamin tracked in Cataclysm, but be careful of vitamin overdose when eating dahlia in real life.
Serving Size is 1 cup of sliced roots. Salsify grows in bountiful clumps, it's a weed.
description: A highly nutritious root, it is tough and bland until cooked, at which point it tastes strangely similar to oysters.
A very bitter root, not meant to be eaten raw.

//: Also known as Queen Anne's Lace. It's that boring white flower that grows wild everywhere. Water hemlock looks almost exactly like wild carrot. The easiest way to tell them apart is by their scent. Please don't eat either of them at home, hemlock will kill you deader than Socrates.
description: These are often wild carrots, but beware of poisonous lookalikes.  In any case, the root is tough and is not as tasty as a real raw carrot.
A stalk of dogbane.  It has very fibrous stems and is mildly poisonous.
A pungent garlic bulb.  Popular as a seasoning for its strong flavor.  Can be disassembled into cloves.
//: Who in their right mind would eat an entire garlic bulb raw?

description: Cloves of garlic.  Useful as a seasoning.
A cluster of small cone-like flowers, indispensable for brewing beer.
A large white tapered root of a horseradish plant.  Way too spicy to eat in this form, but can be used for making condiments.
A crisp head of iceberg lettuce.  You should probably prepare it before eating.
A handful of shredded iceberg lettuce.
A stalk of mugwort.  Smells wonderful.
An aromatic onion used in cooking.  Cutting these up can make your eyes sting!
//: Raw onions probably aren't all that tasty to most people.
wild vegetables as a reference
//2: Legacy note: This is no longer a plant item drop, it only comes from fungaloids.
description: A fluid bladder from a fungus-based lifeform.  Not very nutritious, but safe to eat.
A potato, mildly toxic and not very tasty raw.  Delicious and filling when properly cooked.

A much less sweet and more starchy relative of the banana; unlike dessert bananas, they usually are eaten cooked rather than raw, and can be processed into flour.  They are a staple food in tropical regions of the world.  Also known as plantains.
A large gourd, about the size of a person's head.  It'll require some disassembly before use.
A quarter section of a pumpkin.  The seeds and stringy inner pulp have been removed.
//: Cutting it up makes it viable for rabbits, too.

description: Leaves of a horseradish plant with a sharp, bitter and peppery taste.  They're edible, but not commonly eaten.
//: Lots of negative results for cattle, apparently very much not good for them

description: A handful of freshly-picked yellow dandelions.  In their current raw state they are quite bitter.
Burdock, a bitter thistle-like vegetable.  Can be eaten raw or cooked.
//: Apparently toxic to rabbits

description: Raw woody bamboo shoots, they require some preparation before they can be eaten safely.
A sour stalk of the rhubarb plant, often used in baking pies.
This fleshy root is ripe and flowing with sugars; it'll just take some processing to extract them.
Dried leaves of a tropical plant.  You can boil them into tea, or you can just eat them raw.  They're pretty gross and not too filling that way, though.
//: Tea is sold by weight not by volume. 1 kg of tea has a volume of 3,4 liters. We use smaller packs of at least 100 mg. Such a tea has a volume of 340 ml minus package makes it around 320 ml. 3 g per serving makes 33 charges.

description: These leaves smell strongly medicinal.  When chewed, they first taste sweet but the aftertaste is incredibly bitter.  These leaves contain good amounts of methyl salicylate and merely chewing them may have a similar effect to aspirin.
Dried leaves of a tropical plant.  You can boil them into green tea, or you can just eat them raw.  They're pretty gross and not too filling that way, though.
A juicy red tomato.  It gained popularity in Italy after being brought back from the New World.
A cut-up tomato with the seeds removed.
An weird looking chunk of plant matter that's a shade of yellow and green, with oddly thick fibers.  It smells like a mix of rotted wood and dirt, and it leaks a clear fluid.
//: average of broccoli, cabbage, carrot, cattail_stalk, celery, chili_pepper, cucumber, lettuce, onion, pumpkin, raw_dandelion, rhubarb, sugar_beet, tomato, zucchini
Note: Legacy item ID, this is not actually a vegetable at all anymore.
description: A chunk of fungal matter from some sort of alien mushroom creature.  Eating unfamiliar mushrooms is a bad idea.
An assortment of edible-looking wild plants.  Most are quite bitter-tasting.  Some are inedible until cooked.
//: In real life many root vegetables are mildly toxic until cooked

description: A tasty summer squash.
A chopped-up summer squash.  The seeds have been removed.
Raw, uncooked kidney beans.  They are mildly toxic to humans in this form, but you could cook them to make them tasty.
A handful of immature fern fronds, still curled up like the head of a fiddle.  Delicious when cooked, but consuming them raw can cause food poisoning.
//: Fiddleheads that haven't been boiled can make you sick.  As they are poisonous here, they will get no CATTLE or RABBIT flag as the poison should not get nullified.

description: Some young leaves from miscellaneous plants.  They're tender enough to eat, but not very tasty on their own.
Some chicory greens.  They are quite bitter but high in calcium.
Some young Japanese knotweed stems.  They taste a bit like rhubarb and contain good amounts of vitamin A.  Refreshing.
A green bell pepper.  Eating it whole and raw would be kind of a hassle, considering all the seeds.
A chopped up bell pepper with the seeds removed.
This wheat-free white flour is useful for baking items for those with grain intolerances.
//: 250 ml is equivalent to 1 cup of flour.  10 charges is roughly equivalent to a cup of flour for American recipes.  Nutritional data based off buckwheat flour.

description: A vegetable from the gourd family, bottle gourds were brought to the Americas by the first Native American settlers crossing the Bering strait.  It can be further prepared to produce a hard, watertight shell, usable as a biodegradable liquid container.  Eating it doesn't look worth it.
A normal and healthy purple eggplant.  Needs to be disassembled before being useful for cooking.
A cut-up eggplant with many of the seeds picked out.
A handful of slimy seaweed.  It doesn't look edible, but properly dried, it might make for decent kindling.
A slimy heap of seaweed.  It doesn't look edible, but properly dried, it might make for decent kindling.
A handful of edible green seaweed.  It makes a good snack as-is, but can be dried or prepared in a number of ways.
A sizable strip of new growth harvested from a sugar kelp.  While these are most often dried, it seems edible enough as is.
A leafy bunch of seaweed covered in air bladders.  Many claims are made about its health benefits, but at least as a foodstuff, it's no better or worse than other edible seaweed.
